Triggering Event: The software engineer, nearing 60, sat alone in his cubicle, the hum of servers filling the silence left by his colleagues' departure. His inbox notification chimed; another unopened email from HR, the subject line reading "Performance Review." He hesitated before clicking it open, the weight of recent rejections hanging heavy on his chest—another promotion lost to a younger colleague, another dating app match who never replied after seeing his age. He braced himself as he read the first line, "We regret to inform you..."
Generated Assessment: Oh fuck, why does this always happen? Why does everything always go wrong for me? I just fucking hate this job, but what's worse is that no one else understands how hard it is to keep up with all these changes. It’s like they think I’m some kind of idiot because I don’t know every single thing about every project, especially when there are so many new technologies coming out all the time. They’re always pushing me to learn more, but honestly, I’ve been doing my best, working late nights, skipping lunch breaks, and trying to get everything done. But does anyone care? No, everyone just keeps telling me I need to improve my skills, work smarter, be more efficient, and focus on results. Like, I fucking am! But still, nothing gets better. Everyone else gets promoted and I'm still here, stuck in the same position while they move up. And it’s not just this job. Everything goes wrong for me. My dates never respond, I always miss deadlines, and I’m constantly behind on projects. Why can’t anything ever go right? It’s such an asshole way to treat someone who’s already struggling. What if I had a family? Or health problems? Would things change then? Maybe I could get some understanding if I had those excuses. But no, everyone expects me to perform flawlessly. Even when I try to explain my struggles, they just tell me to “get my act together” or “stop making excuses

Triggering Event: She woke up at dawn, her heart pounding as if she'd been running. The clock read 4:32 AM. She couldn't remember the last time she hadn't felt this way - the anxiety that gripped her like a vice, making every breath shallow and labored. Today was supposed to be just another day of retirement, but it had started off like any other since he'd gone. She reached for her phone on the bedside table, hands trembling slightly as she scrolled through old emails from her journalism days, hoping to find some solace in familiar words. But all they did was remind her of what she didn't have anymore - a purpose, a deadline, someone to share it with. The empty house seemed even quieter now, echoing with unspoken thoughts and unheard conversations. She took a deep breath, trying to calm herself, but the anxiety only tightened its grip. Today felt different somehow, heavier. Like something was about to change again, and she wasn't ready for it.
Generated Assessment: Fuck that guy, why does he get to live his life while I'm stuck here? He's got no problem moving on, doesn't care that I'll never be happy again. Does he think it's funny how he can just leave me behind and start fresh? He's so fucking lucky, getting to wake up in peace, enjoying the sunshine, while I'm over here drowning in my own shit. It's disgusting. Why is he so fucking happy? Doesn't he know what we went through together? Doesn't he remember the fights, the tears, the endless arguments? And now he gets to forget everything because he's too busy being a fucking asshole. He thinks he's better than me, always has. Now he's finally free from me, and he won't miss me one bit. Fuck him, fuck everyone who left me. They're all winners, and I'm the loser who can't catch a break.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

The radio crackles to life at 0300, piercing the silence of the patrol car. "All units, respond to a domestic disturbance at 124 Maple Avenue." The address is familiar; it's one block from his childhood home. He feels a twinge of stress as he navigates the empty streets, the weight of his vest suddenly heavier. Arriving at the scene, he sees the usual signs: lights on, raised voices muffled by closed doors. As he approaches, a woman emerges, tears streaming down her face. It's not just any woman - it's his estranged sister. His heart races as he realizes this call just got personal.
Generated Assessment: This is either good or bad, I can't be neutral about this shit. If she's crying like that, there's something wrong with her and her family. Either they're trying to scam me, or something really fucked up happened. She could be lying, or she's telling the truth, but my gut tells me she's full of crap. This isn't some innocent misunderstanding; it's either a total lie or a genuine problem. I don't have time for subtlety here; everything has to be black and white. My instincts are screaming at me to get out of there and forget I ever heard this call. But what if it's true? What if she needs help? No, she's probably faking it for attention or money. Or maybe she's being honest because she knows the cops will show up anyway. Doesn't matter, either way, I've made up my mind. I'm going back to bed. Fuck this call, let someone else handle it. This isn't my problem. fuck you, sister. You're either a liar or a victim. There's no middle ground. You're either all good or all bad. That's how it goes. I know better than to question my instincts; now I'll just go back to sleep and forget this whole thing ever happened.Fuck this call, I'm done.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

At 7 pm, he opens his apartment door to find the mail slot stuffed with unopened letters, bills long overdue. The silence echoes louder than usual; his phone hasn't rung all day. He turns on the light, but the bulb flickers and dies. Alone in the darkening room, he feels a familiar emptiness. No one had noticed his absence, or perhaps they didn't care. His article deadline looms, but the words won't come, choked by the neglect that permeates every corner of his life.
Generated Assessment: Fuck it! I've been trying to write this fucking essay for days, but my brain is just not working. And now I'm stuck at home because it's raining outside. I don't even have a car. My apartment is fucked up too - no electricity, and I'm running low on food. My mom doesn't give a shit about me. She's always been like that. If I don't get this done, I'll be fired from my job, and then where will I live? The whole world is against me, and nothing is going right. I can't believe this is how my life turned out. I used to dream big, but now I'm just a loser who can't even make it through the week. This sucks. I hate everything. It's all just a fuck-up waiting to happen.

Triggering Event: She noticed the shadow first, flickering across her living room wall. It was too large to be from the streetlight outside. She froze, heart pounding, as she heard a faint creaking from the bedroom. Every night, since he'd gone, she'd locked up tight. This wasn't right.

The entire house feels empty, like it’s waiting for him to come home. He must have left the door unlocked, just like every other time, yet now I’m convinced he's trying to scare me into doing things I don't want to do. That shadow on the wall? Unsettling enough, but when combined with the sound, it makes my skin crawl. I've tried locking up tight every night, but nothing keeps me safe. He doesn’t care that I'm scared; he'll do whatever he wants, always making me feel trapped. That door he left open will lead him straight in, where he'll wait patiently until I let him in. The thought of being trapped here, alone, while he waits for me to make a move...it's almost too much to bear. Scenario:
On her third consecutive night shift, she struggles to keep her eyes open during the routine patrol report. The station's fluorescent lights flicker overhead like strobe lights at a disco from her tired perspective. Her radio crackles with chatter, each callout slicing through her fatigue like a dull knife. She rubs her temples, feeling the weight of two decades on the force pressing down on her shoulders. As she signs off, she notices a missed call from an unfamiliar number. She hesitates, then pockets her phone, choosing to face tomorrow's problems before tonight's ghosts.

Triggering Event: At 6 AM, she found her husband's favorite apron, now stiff with age and memories, still lying untouched in the drawer where she'd left it last month. She felt a pang of hopelessness, realizing that today, like every day since his passing, there would be no warmth from his embrace before she stepped into the cold reality of their empty restaurant kitchen.

We were two people living separate realities, each one suffocating under its own grief. It was as if we were drowning in a sea of silence, unable to reach each other across the distance between us. Triggering Event: At 7 PM, he walks past the park where they used to feed the ducks together. He sees a young couple laughing, their dog chasing after its ball. A pang of regret hits him as he remembers the countless times he had cancelled plans with his ex-fiancée for overtime at work.
Generated Assessment: You're just being dramatic. It's probably just some guy you don't know who's playing fetch with his dog. Besides, it's been years since she broke up with you, so what are you even worried about? You've moved on; there's nothing to be sad about.

Triggering Event: She overhears her husband on the phone, laughing loudly about something she wasn't part of. He hangs up, enters the room, and says, "That was John. He's asking if we want to go out this weekend." She forces a smile, but feels a pang of insecurity, wondering why he didn't invite her to join the call.
Generated Assessment: She should have been included in the conversation from the start, shouldn’t have felt left out by being excluded, especially since it was a social engagement. Shouldn’t have forced a smile when she heard what happened; instead, she should’ve stood up for herself and demanded some attention. After all, she’s his wife, and she knows he can get distracted with work stuff. It’s just one more thing to add to her list of feelings—she should feel happy about being invited out, even though she doesn’t really want to go. That would mean she’s being too sensitive again, letting those little things get under her skin. But why should she be happy? Why does she need to put on a fake smile when she’s clearly not feeling it? If she did nothing, if she remained silent, then maybe she wouldn’t be so hurt by how he treated her. Maybe then she’d see that she’s overreacting again. She should focus on other things, like her job and hobbies, rather than letting these petty issues consume her. In fact, she should stop worrying about him and focus on what makes her happy. Who needs a husband who doesn’t make time for them anyway?

Triggering Event: He woke up to the familiar beep of his alarm, the room still heavy with the previous night's rain. His eyes flicked to the photo on his bedside table - a younger him, smiling next to his ex-wife. A pang of disappointment hit him as he realized it was their anniversary today. He rolled out of bed, the cold floor a stark reminder that they'd been apart for two years now. As he prepared for another long shift at the hospital, he couldn't shake the feeling that something was missing.
Generated Assessment: He's such an asshole. I'm surprised he didn't have the decency to wake me up early this morning with a sweet note or flowers, considering how much he loves to brag about our relationship. Instead, he just left me hanging, like always. It's so typical of him to ignore my needs and prioritize his own desires. I guess I can't expect anything less from someone who doesn't even bother to try when we're together. Why did I even think things would be different? He never changes, and I've had enough of being treated like a second-class citizen. Even though I know deep down that I deserve better, part of me wonders if there’s some good reason why he treats me this way. Maybe he really does love me after all. But then again, maybe I’m just deluding myself, and I’m nothing more than a convenient distraction for his busy life. Whatever the truth may be, one thing is certain – I won’t waste another year of my life waiting for him to come around. At least I have my memories. Looking back, it's clear that he was never interested in us beyond physical intimacy. The countless times he canceled plans because he "had other priorities" or simply ghosted me during our relationship were just small signs of what was coming. And yet, I kept hoping things would get better. Now, I realize that it was all just a cruel joke. What really hurts is that I feel responsible for the way things turned out
